thread.title: Check out that rear end: Evolution of F1 cars
thread.title_full: Check out that rear end: Evolution of F1 cars

title: Check out that rear end: Evolution of F1 cars
text:
Feb 23, 2017 at 12:26p ET 0Shares The classics 
Giorgio Scarlatti drives a Maserati 250F en route to a sixth place finish at the 1957 Pescara GP. LAT Photographic Shiny hiney 
There was no rear wing or bodywork throughout most of the 1960’s. Here, Jim Clark is seen racing his Lotus 33-Climax en route to a fifth place finish at the 1964 Mexican GP. LAT Photographic New look 
At the 1960’s came to a close, wings and wedge-shaped bodies were beginning to enter the sport. LAT Photographic LAT Photographic 
Formula One cars seen navigating the Kleine Chicane during the 1973 Belgian GP at Zolder. LAT Photographic LAT Photographic Perfection 
The Lotus 79 - pictured here at Goodwood in 2014 - performed as well as it looked during the 1978 Formula One season, giving Mario Andretti the World Championship. LAT Photographic A Eighties evolution 
The F1 cars began to look much more modern in the 1980’s, although they still weren't very tall and they still featured wide rear tires. Here, Niki Lauda races en route to victory at the 1984 Italian GP. LAT Photographic Sparky! 
It was a common sight to see the beautiful Ferrari F641 kicked up sparks during the 1990 Formula One season, as Alain Prost did here en route to victory at Spain. LAT Photographic Last good-looking cars? 
Following the 1997 season, the F1 cars were narrowed and slick tires were banned from the sport. Here, Michael Schumacher leads championship rival Jacques Villeneuve in Jerez. The two would collide later in the race, with Villeneuve taking home the title. LAT Photographic 
David Coulthard seen competing in his McLaren Mercedes MP4/19 during the 2004 German Grand Prix. LAT Photographic Where did we go wrong? 
Cars seen sitting at the exit of pit road ahead of qualifying for the 2013 Malaysia GP. LAT Photographic They’re back! 
New regulations for 2017 mean the cars aren't as tall and are wider than before. Additionally, they also feature wider Pirelli tires. LAT Photographic Glenn Dunbar
